raw_text:
Lewis-Francis eyeing world gold
 
 Mark Lewis-Francis says his Olympic success has made him determined to bag World Championship 100m gold in 2005.
 
 The 22-year-old pipped Maurice Greene on the last leg of the 4x100m relay in Athens to take top honours for Team GB. But individually, the Birchfield Harrier has yet to build on his World Junior Championship win four years ago. "The gold medal in Athens has made me realise that I can get to the top level and I want to get there again. It can happen, I don't see why not," he said. Lewis-Francis has still to decided what events will feature in his build-up to the worlds - with one exception. He has confirmed his participation in the Norwich Union Grand Prix in Birmingham on 18 February, where he will take on another member of Britain's victorious men's relay team - Jason Gardener - over 60m. He added: "It's a bit too early to make any predictions for Helsinki, but I have my eyes open and I know I can be the best in the world."
llama3.2:1b: Mark Lewis-Francis aims for World Championship 100m gold in 2005 after winning Team GB's relay medal. His Olympic success has boosted his confidence, prompting him to target individual gold. He will participate in events leading up to Worlds, with an exception being Norwich Union Grand Prix on February 18.
llama3.2:3b: Mark Lewis-Francis aims to win World Championship gold in 100m after Olympic success, which motivated him to reach top level. The 22-year-old has yet to build on his World Junior Championship win four years ago and will participate in the Norwich Union Grand Prix in Birmingham before the worlds.
gemma2:2b: Mark Lewis-Francis aims to win gold at the 2005 World Championship after achieving success in the Olympics. He believes his victory in Athens has motivated him to further his career and achieve even greater heights. He plans to participate in the Norwich Union Grand Prix, where he will race against Jason Gardener, another member of Team GB's relay team. Lewis-Francis remains optimistic about his potential for success at the World Championships in Helsinki.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Lewis-Francis is determined to bag World Championship golds in 2005 after his Olympic success as he aims to build on his individual success with Norwich Union Grand Prix.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Lewis-Francis aims to win World Championship 100m gold in 2005 after Olympic success. He has confirmed participation in the Norwich Union Grand Prix alongside a team member from Athens relay victory.
qwen2.5:3b: Lewis-Francis aims for World Championship gold in 2005 after Olympic success, focusing on building individual performance. He has qualified for the Norwich Union Grand Prix in February to compete against Jason Gardener over 60m. Despite his relay victory in Athens, he wants to win a personal world title.

The 22-year-old pipped Maurice Greene on the last leg of the 4x100m relay in Athens to take top honours for Team GB. But individually, the Birchfield Harrier has yet to build on his World Junior Championship win four years ago. "The gold medal in Athens has made me realise that I can get to the top level and I want to get there again. It can happen, I don't see why not," he said.

Lewis-Francis has still to decided what events will feature in his build-up to the worlds - with one exception. smollm:1.7b: Lewis-Francis has yet to build on his World Junior Championship win four years ago.
deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Okay, so I need to summarize this text about Lewis-Francis and his training for the World Championship. Let me read through it carefully.

He mentions he's determined for the 100m World gold in 2005 after winning an Olympic and doing well in another relay. That's good to know. Then, he talks about how he beat Maurice Greene last leg at Athens but hasn't done much since his Junior win. He's optimistic about getting back to top level and mentions the Norwich Union Grand Prix in Birmingham where he'll team with Jason Gardener for a 60m event.

He has "too early" to predict Helsinki, but it's too late. I should capture all that key points without any explanations or formatting. Just plain text summarizing everything.
</think>

Lewis-Francis determined to win the 100m World gold in 2005 after Olympic success and relay performance. Confident about advancing to world level, he'll train with Jason Gardener for a future 60m event. Uncertain about Helsinki but optimistic for Norwich Union Grand Prix next year.
tinyllama:1.1b: The Olympic gold medal that Lewis-Francis achieved at the last leg of the 4x100m relay has propelled him to become a determined contender for World Championship 100m gold in 2005. The Birchfield Harriss also aspired to return to the top level after their respective triumphs in Athens four years ago. Although they have yet to secure such honours, Lewis-Francis has set his sights on winning the world title after making a name for himself during the Norwich Union Grand Prix at Birminingham in February. The 22-year-old, who won the World Junior Championship title two years ago, has yet to declare his participation but confirmed that he will take part over 60m in Helsinki.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Mark Lewis-Francis has been eyeing Olympic success with his victory in the 4x100m relay in Athens four years ago. Now, at 22, he's aiming to win a World Championship 100m gold and is considering participating in the Norwich Union Grand Prix in Birmingham on February 18th, alongside another member of Britain's victorious men's relay team, Jason Gardener. This will be the first time Lewis-Francis races against his former rival, Maurice Greene, who won a silver medal at the 4x100m relay in Athens.
phi:2.7b: Mark Lewis-Francis won the 4x100m relay at the 2004 Olympics and is determined to win World Championship 100m gold in 2005. He has not yet been able to replicate his success as an individual athlete. However, he confirmed his participation in a race against Jason Gardener in Birmingham on 18 February 2005.
orca-mini:3b: Lewis-Francis is eyeing gold in the World Championship 100m race in 2005. He won the Olympic 4x100m relay in Athens in 2004, but has yet to win a World Championship medal individually. He plans to participate in the Norwich Union Grand Prix in Birmingham on February 18th, where he will face Jason Gardener over 60m.
hermes3:3b: Mark Le-Wis-Francis plans to win World Champ 100m gold, motivated by Athens Olympics success.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: Mark Lewis-Francis aims to win the World Championship 100m gold in 2005, building on his Olympic success and previous World Junior Championship win. He will participate in the Norwich Union Grand Prix in Birmingham on 18 February before making predictions for Helsinki.
stablelm2:1.6b: Mark Lewis-Francis aims to win the World Championship gold by participating in major competitions and focusing on improvement. His Olympic success inspired him to aim for the top level, with no reason not to achieve it. He hasn 3t yet built upon his World Junior Championship win but intends to participate in the Norwich Union Grand Prix and possibly other events leading up to the 2005 World Championships, although he has not made any predictions regarding that year's event.
granite3.1-dense:2b: Mark Lewis-Friscos, after securing Olympic gold in the 4x100m relay at Athens 2004, aims for a World Championship 100m gold in 2005. Despite his individual World Junior Championship win four years prior, he has yet to excel in this event. Lewis-Friscos is still determining his events for the build-up, but he's confirmed his participation in the Norwich Union Grand Prix in Birmingham on 18 February, where he'll compete against fellow Olympic relay team member Jason Gardener. He remains optimistic about his prospects for the Helsinki World Championships, expressing confidence in his potential to become the world's best.

Confident in his potential, he is planning his build-up to the event, with his only confirmed race being the Norwich Union Grand Prix in Birmingham on 18 February, where he will compete against teammate Jason Gardener in the 60m. While not making early predictions for Helsinki, he believes he can be the best in the world.
